notes: Information of arrivals into and departures from New Granada’s ports is only available for selected ports (Cartagena and Santa Marta) and selected years (1785, 1789, 1793, 1800, 1801, 1807, 1808, 1814, 1817). Similarly, information about foreign vessels—including many Spanish vessels from New Granada—entering the free ports of Jamaica only exists for selected years between 1767 and 1818. While exploring French, Dutch, and Danish archives could enhance the quality of the picture of the participation of New Granada’s ports in the Caribbean commercial networks, that picture would necessarily continue to be incomplete.

The quote is from Lorenzo Corbacho in a report to viceroy José Manuel de Ezpeleta. Complaining voices also included Cartagena’s merchant Juan de León y Páez who informed Ezpeleta that “the navigation to [foreign] colonies to negotiate slaves, is simply a pretext to trade in clothes.” Based on these reports Ezpeleta concluded that in the viceroyalty of New Granada the legal trade in slaves functioned as “a shadow for contraband.” Corbacho to Ezpeleta, Portobelo, November 6, 1794, AGI, Santa Fe, 645, No. 4; Corbacho to Ezpeleta, Portobelo, February 22, 1795, AGI, Santa Fe, 645, No. 5; Leo´n y Pa´ez to Ezpeleta, Cartagena, October 30, 1794, AGI, Santa Fe, 645, No. 1; Ezpeleta to Lerena, Santa Fe. December 19, 1791, AGI, Santa Fe, 640, no. 201.

For the fiction of “imperial self-sufficiency” see David Hancock, Oceans of Wine: Madeira and the Emergence of American Trade and Taste (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2009). Many other works including Lauren Benton, A Search for Sovereignty: Law and Geography in European Empires, 1400-1900 (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2010); Linda Rupert, Creolization and Contraband: Curaçao in the Early Modern Atlantic World (Athens: University of Georgia Press, 2012); Eliga Gould, “Entangled Histories, Entangled Worlds: The English-Speaking Atlantic as Spanish Periphery,” American Historical Review 112/3 (2007): 764-786; Jorge Cañizares-Esguerra, “Entangled Histories: Borderland Historiographies in New Clothes?” American Historical Review 112/3 (June 2007), 787-799; James Sweet, Domingos Álvares, African Healing, and the Intellectual History of the Atlantic World (Chapel Hill: University of Carolina Press, 2011); and Ernesto Bassi, “Beyond Compartmentalized Atlantics: A Case for Embracing the Atlantic from Spanish American Shores,” History Compass 12:9 (2014), 704-716 are increasingly thinking of imperial borders as porous, permeable, fluid, and entangled. For a recent summary of the problem and ongoing trends to solve it see Jorge Cañizares-Esguerra and Benjamin Breen, “Hybrid Atlantics: Future Directions for the History of the Atlantic World,” History Compass 11/8 (2013: 597-609.
